author: DrathMaul1997
title: Far better than it looks!
review:
Parts
Very nice indeed, with almost all parts now rare/hard to find. You get 6 missile bottoms, four of which are light gray, two the very rare (not to mention rather cool) transparent red. Also included are two yellow pipes, these are rare at the best of times, and you certainly can't get them in this colour now-a-days. The not-so-rare-yet-still-hard-to-find parts are the seat, three black 1x4 offset plates (4590), two green 'discs' and two levers.

Minifigure
Not much to say really, it's the 'red' classic space man, who comes with air-tanks and the old 'no-visor' helmet.

Overall
Looking at the picture of this on Brickset I thought "that looks rubbish", however after having it bought for me as a Christmas present I withdraw my opinion. This set is very cute, and can be used for many things; as a civilian vehicle, a forward scout or a messenger's rocket pack.

Is it worth buying? Yes, if you can get this for 2-3 pound off eBay it's very good value (even more so if you buy another set off the seller). A good pocket money set, and a good 'stocking stuffer' for your child.

Thank for reading!

author: CamberbrickGreen
title: Hopping Mad
review:
Why this one sticks in the memory, can only be guessed at for its crazy coloured strange bits. Up there among the best of the classic space mini-vehicles, this model is a bonkers cluster of very spacey bricks and pieces.

Minifigures:

[··][··][··][··][··]

The Red astronaut: more popular and iconic than Heinz Tomato Ketchup. The designer decided to equip him with some flashy kit in the form of a scanner or ray emitter of some sort with a transparent cosmic green disc attached.

Jumping Jack Flash
He sits on top of some gravity defying or gravity reversing little rig, its four chunky thrusters sitting flat on the ground as feet. These are attached with the black two stud plus two offset circular stud bricks, strange bits indeed.

A space seat (cool as click) sits on top for him to ride in while joystick controls go in front on top of the black offsets. The rear of the seat incorporates two more offsets with transparent red thrusters, continuing Lego Space theme's weird technology. These appear to be the astronaut's main propulsion forward.

They then manage to link to the rear downward Surface Hopper thrust via x2 of what looks like Buck Roger's starship fighter disco fuel lines. These translucent banana yellow pipes just extend the space tech into the next dimension, leaving a trail of odd space junk and bricks that sadly have disappeared into classic deep space.

Refreshingly different to other spacecraft in the mini fleet from Classic Space, this is one of the best. An inventive and wonderful tiny design.

author: T79
title: Hop on, hop off. Hop on - well, you get the idea
review:
When I was a child this set was never among my favourites, it seemed like such a waste of perfectly fine pieces to just use all of them on this small chair - they had to be used for grander things! A good number of years later and some sons of my own, maybe it's time to take a second opinion: this weekend we built all sets we have from 21 up to and including 25 pieces, from 1974's #612 Tipper Truck (honourable mention for this one as it was the first one they chose to build and still was a tempting choice between all the other small sets) to 2008's #5616 Mini-Robot (looks a bit like Wall-E!). While #6009 Black Knight and #5612 Police Officer (the dog, really) were tempting they went with this Surface Hopper in the end, traitors under my own roof!

Box/Instructions

Again, a standard small folding sheet with the usual moon background used for space sets. Par for the course it shows some alternatives of questionable quality although the lack of generic bricks and plates makes it hard to do something different.

Parts

As mentioned above, there is not one standard brick or plate to be found in this set, the part selection is as outrageous as the piece count is humble: the entire chair is built out of four 1 x 4 plate with two offset studs, a space chair, six round bricks with fins (four in grey - this is the greatest quantity of them in any one set except for DACTA - and two in trans-red) and, saving the best for last, two trans-yellow hoses. These only appeared in a good handful of sets and this is the smallest set they came in. Two trans-green 2 x 2 dishes (my favourite colour for this part back then), a robot arm and two levers and all parts are mentioned.

Minifigures

Just one red classic space astronaut, this time he comes with a robot arm which gets pimped with a trans-green dish to make a scanner/blaster/signal detection array/whatever. The Surface Hopper is controlled by two levers and the astronaut can only manipulate one when he has his tool in hand. I wonder if this was intentional on the designer's part but since this tool is a robot arm the astronaut could still grip the lever with his tool in hand!

The build

Real quick, put those offset plates on the chair, use the bricks with fins on those offset plates and then connect some of them using the hoses. Even for a small set like this there is nothing special to it.

The completed model

Another one of those queer-looking classic space sets (cfr. #6882 Walking Astro Grappler) and it is on those grounds I dismissed this as a child, fortunately my children have more sense than their father ;)

Overall opinion

Well, this was chosen as the set they would keep if forced to pick just one and I think the competition in this group (21-25 parts) was pretty stiff so enough said! I did expect more from #6245 Harbour Sentry though...
